TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Clayey-skeletal, mixed, superactive, frigid Lithic Xeric Haplocambids

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Donning very gravelly loam, range.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
A11--0 to 3 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) very gravelly loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; weak fine granular structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; many roots; 45 percent pebbles, 15 percent cobbles and 5 percent stones; neutral (pH 7.2); clear smooth boundary.  (2 to 7 inches thick)
A12--3 to 7 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) very gravelly clay loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; moderate fine subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky, plastic; common roots; 40 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles and 5 percent stones; mildly alkaline (pH 7.4); clear smooth boundary.  (0 to 5 inches thick)
B21--7 to 12 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) very gravelly heavy clay loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; moderate fine subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky, plastic; common roots; 40 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles and 5 percent stones; mildly alkaline (pH 7.8); clear smooth boundary.  (4 to 8 inches thick)
B22--12 to 16 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) very gravelly clay loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; moderate fine subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky, plastic; common roots; 30 percent gravel, 25 percent cobbles and 20 percent stones; mildly alkaline (pH 7.6); abrupt wavy boundary.  (2 to 4 inches thick)
R--16 inches; light colored volcanic tuff breccia.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Wheeler County, Oregon; about 18 miles west of Fossil on state highway 218, 0.2 mile west of junction with county road going up John Day River, 100 feet north of highway; NE1/4 SE1/4 section 33, T. 7 S., R. 19 E., Willamette Meridian.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mean annual soil temperature ranges from 51 to 54 degrees F. (estimated).  The moisture regime is aridic that borders on xeric.  Depth to the lithic contact ranges from 10 to 20 inches.  Rock fragments in the control section range from 35 to 70 percent.  They consist mainly of pebbles and cobbles, but can have 10 to 30 percent stones.
The A horizon has value of 4 through 6 dry and 3 or 4 moist and chroma of 2 or 3 moist and dry with 20 to 50 percent pebbles, 10 to 20 percent cobbles and 0 to 10 percent stones.
The B horizon has value of 5 or 6 dry and 4 moist and chroma of 3 or 4 moist and dry.  It is clay or clay loam or silty clay loam with an average of 35 to 45 percent clay.  It has moderate or weak subangular blocky structure.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Lorella, Pulsipher, Ruckles and Waterbury series.  The Lorella, Ruckles and Waterbury soils have mollic epipedons and argillic horizons.  Pulsipher soils are loamy-skeletal.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Donning soils are mainly on south facing slopes in uplands with slopes ranging from 30 to 70 percent and at elevations of 1,300 to 2,500 feet.  They have formed in residuum and colluvium weathered from Clarno age volcanic tuff.  Average annual precipitation is 9 to 11 inches.  Mean annual temperature is about 50 degrees F., mean summer temperature is about 64 degrees F., and mean winter temperature is about 34 degrees F.  Average frost-free period is 100 to 150 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Day, Lickskillet, Simas and Sorf soils.  All of these soils are deeper than 20 inches to bedrock.  In addition, Day soils have intersecting slickensides, Simas soils have mollic epipedons and argillic horizons, and Sorf soils have argillic horizons.  Lickskillet soils are loamy-skeletal and are 10 to 20 inches deep over basalt bedrock.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; rapid runoff; low permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Donning soils are used for range.  Native vegetation dominantly is matchweed, purple sage, bluebunch wheatgrass, Sandberg bluebrass and Thurber needlegrass.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  East central Oregon, The series is of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Portland, Oregon

ORIGIN.content: SERIES PROPOSED:  Wheeler County, Oregon, 1973.  The name is from moderate extent.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  These soils would have been classified as Lithosols.  The organic matter is assumed to be less than 1 percent in the upper 7 inches when mixed.
NSTH 17, RECLASSIFICATION ONLY, 3/95
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
